thread.title: Texas Rangers players, fans and media upset over defensive errors, Bautista bat
thread.title_full: Texas Rangers players, fans and media upset over defensive errors, Bautista bat

author: Postmedia Network
title: Texas Rangers players, fans and media upset over defensive errors, Bautista bat
text:
As the Toronto Blue Jays celebrated a Game 5 winner-take-all victory on Wednesday at Rogers Centre, Texas Rangers players were attempting to stay diplomatic about where it all went wrong.
Front and centre was Jose Bautista's game-winning home run.
It wasn't as much the homer that seemed to anger the Rangers, but Bautista's exaggerated bat flip and slow trot around the bases following the game-winning three-run blast.
"It's hard to be politically correct, but you want to be able to play the game the right way," Rangers starting pitcher Cole Hamels told the Fort Worth Star-Telegram after the game. "You've got a lot of kids who are watching. You just want to be a ballplayer, and I think there's a certain amount of respect that you've got to have."
The Texas media didn't put it so politely.
According to The Dallas Morning News writer Gerry Fraley , "the Rangers have a new certified No. 1 villain: Jose Bautista."
"Bautista's histrionics, which included a world indoor record for the bat flip after the homer during an epic seventh inning, raised the Rangers' ire," he said.
For his part, Bautista says he doesn't remember what happened after his home run.
"I can't really remember what was going through my mind," he told reporters . "After I made contact, you know, I didn't plan anything that I did, so I still don't even know how i did it."
"The bat flip? This is a celebration. He's allowed to do whatever he wants in my book," Blue Jays third baseman Josh Donaldson added.
It wasn't just the media in the Lone Star state that took note of Bautista's bat flip.
The New York Times posted a story pondering if baseball has officially entered "a golden age of celebratory antics" after New York Mets slugger Yoenis Cespedes' flip on Monday at Citi Field and then Bautista's on Wednesday at Rogers Centre.
"(Cespedes') majestic flip would be reduced to a quaint memory two nights later, when Jose Bautista of the Toronto Blue Jays performed what might have been the most ostentatious bat flip in MLB history."
Who flipped it better? #OwnOctober https://t.co/jVXRdGKdvF
â€” MLB (@MLB) October 15, 2015 Bautista's big blast to left field may have given the Blue Jays the lead, but it was self-inflicted defensive errors that set the stage for the Rangers' downfall.
Kevin Sherrington of the Dallas Morning News called the "mind-boggling defensive collapse" in Game 5 "as bad as World Series nightmare" from 2011.
"Here's how devastating the bottom of the seventh was: It nearly made you forget the top half of the inning, which only included one of the craziest plays in anyone's postseason history," he said.
That crazy play came at the top half of the inning when a rule even plate umpire Dale Scott admitted to not knowing allowed the Rangers to take the lead, followed by a showering of beer cans, water bottles and anything else Blue Jays fans could get their hands on to throw on the field.
But it was three big errors - one by Rangers first baseman Mitch Moreland and two by shortstop Elvis Andrus - that changed everything for Texas.
After Andrus told reporters he felt he should have made both plays and that he let his team down, here's how Gil Lebreton put it for the Star Telegram :
"They were all simple answers and reeked of contrition. But what do you say at the gates of baseball hell?"
Thank u guys for all the support in this though moment in my career this is just the beginning of something that is bigger than today game
â€” Elvis Andrus (@ElvisandrusSS1) October 15, 2015 So proud of this team. This is going to make us stronger. It's going to sting but so proud how we #NeverEverQuit and the class we showed.
â€” Jake Diekman (@JakeDiekman) October 15, 2015 As for Rangers' fans on the Game 5 loss, they weren't too fond of the bat flip or the errors.
What is with the TEXAS RANGERS and feelin' the pressure? Wow, I feel for ELVIS ANDRUS. Yeah, I do. pic.twitter.com/smjghK18Rd
â€” Rip Nottmeyer (@riptalkinsports) October 15, 2015 Don't get anger at @JoeyBats19 for bat flip. As a @Rangers fan, the 3 errors leading up to it are what gets me. Gotta make plays. Jose did.
â€” Nathan Lovato (@CleanSpaceInc) October 15, 2015 I love the #TexasRangers . But hey #SamDyson and the rest of the #Rangers , if you don't like the #batflip , don't give up the big home run.
â€” Joey Sampson (@jsampsonlaw) October 15, 2015 Dear baseball gods, I think it's time to stop with the torture of Texas Rangers fans.
â€” Greg Pearson (@gregspearson) October 15, 2015 One day later, while disappointed in how @Rangers season ended, still proud of the year they had.
â€” Chris Fox (@silentkid70) October 15, 2015 Thank you Texas Rangers fans - found on the Blue Jays Facebook comments. All class! https://t.co/AVnp7LqnQI pic.twitter.com/uiozhFXW2N
â€” Alex (@northstoryCA) October 15, 2015 @ElvisandrusSS1 Bro. That was rough. I probably couldn't look you in the eyes for a couple of days. But I still got your back. ðŸ‘»
â€” Matt Fisher (@NextWaveMLB) October 15, 2015 Scare Rangers fans at Halloween with new Jose... http://t.co/Fy7U8NMgmg #TexasRangers | https://t.co/RztISeL5Ek pic.twitter.com/HdywRl4UZW
â€” Texas Rangers Fans (@TXRangersFandom) October 15, 2015 Elvis andrus single handedly lost this baseball game
â€” Lucas Schmiedendorf (@lschmieds) October 14, 2015 As the Blue Jays' partying continued late into the night, Rangers players, fans and media alike were left wondering what could have been if not for " the 53 minutes that changed the Rangers' destiny ."
The Blue Jays will take on the Kansas City Royals in the American League Championship Series beginning on Friday.
